subject: meta-google: gbmc-ncsi-config: Restrict NCSI input packets
commitMessage:
meta-google: gbmc-ncsi-config: Restrict NCSI input packets

Break down packets by their incoming address and ensure that we don't
allow packets to unintended destinations. Right now this is effectively
a no-op, but it will be necessary for BMC public addressing.

Change-Id: I39c16c3b9cd4c293df42b928674e39677d7834e9
Signed-off-by: William A. Kennington III <wak@google.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 1ef795b90e4d87f58553afbcf5928728ffb86e1b by William A. Kennington III
Not familiar with these rules files so would like someone else to review.

It wasn't obvious to me (or it was hard to find the documentation) that local -n links them as name reference variable, as I was confused as to how `gbmc_ncsi_nft_lastip*`was getting updated.

Possibly worth noting down in comment for future readers?
I see that the variables declared in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/41207 are being used here - how do they call each other?
Use global modifier to sed
Done
nit: 72 char
Done
Question: what do these dollar signs mean?

This is required to insert escaped character (in particular case as new line symbol).
Usually, it something like this:
```
  contents += $'table inet filter{\n'
```
Thanks for the explanation.
what does nos stand for?
It should be a substring replacement. This should drop colon. Not sure, if it's global replacement or only for the first occurance (I'm not a bashisms fan :)

Doh! Didn't realize we could call ${parameter//pattern/string} directly from bash.

Quoting this answer: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13210880/replace-one-substring-for-another-string-in-shell-script

> To replace the first occurrence of a pattern with a given string, use ${parameter/pattern/string}:
>To replace all occurrences, use ${parameter//pattern/string}:

So yes, this seems to be global replcaement.
I'm a little lost here, what does ${#variable} do?
This is the length of the string
Ah, thanks! It's hard to google things when they're special characters :(
Yeah, the bash syntax for string manipulations is a bit terse and hard to look up.
